--- "J. B. Rainsberger" wrote:
> Well, for my purposes, code coverage isn't /so/
> important. I would only 
> use it, at this point, as integrated with Maven.

I advocate a certain style of development (and perhaps
a tool to go with it). If I have N hours of
development/testing left before I have to switch to my
next task or risk causing scheduling problems, I would
use a code coverage tool with drill-down report
capabilities to highlight which areas of the codebase
need most attention.

Testing absolutely everything is not feasible (or even
useful) in practice. By comparison, knowing how best
to partition your remaining on-task time to get the
best mileage out of your test is valuable.

Not particularly novel, I suppose, but different from
the traditional approach of merely validating code
coverage (usually when it's too late to do the right
thing about it).

Using a static analysis or a code coverage tool to
direct you towards product areas that need attention
and doing it in a team environment has become possible
only recently, with the advent of tools that are:

- free, so software licensing for large teams is a
non-issue
- fast, so that rapid "code some, test some" iterative
work remains rapid

In a modest way, EMMA tries to be one such tool.

Cheers,
Vlad.
